'''Fruteland Jackson''' (born June 9, 1953) is an American [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry Townsend]] stated, "My respect for Fruteland Jackson is very high. He and my boy [[Alvin Youngblood Hart]] is the future sound of true acoustic blues."<ref name="Electrofi">{{cite web|url=http://www.electrofi.com/bio_fruteland.htm|title=Fruteland Jackson|publisher=Electrofi.com|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> He has also worked with children to raise awareness of blues music and has been honored for his work in that field, including in 1997 being granted a [[Blues Music Award|W. C. Handy Award]] for "Keeping the Blues Alive" in Education.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Delta">{{cite book
| first= Fruteland
| last= Jackson
| year= 1999
| title= Guitar Roots: Delta Blues - The roots of great guitar playing
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Alfred Publishing Co. 
| location= [[Van Nuys, California]], United States
| isbn= 0-7390-3006-X
| page= 2}}</ref> 

Since 2000, Jackson has released three [[album]]s.<ref name="AMG"/>
 
==Life and career==
Jackson was born in [[Doddsville, Mississippi]], the son of an insurance underwriter, and he relocated with his family to [[Chicago]] in the 1960s in order to secure better employment and education outlooks.  His father was employed by [[North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company|North Carolina Mutual Insurance Company]], and his mother worked as a nurse at Chicago's [[John H. Stroger, Jr. Hospital of Cook County|Cook County Hospital]].  He received his first guitar from his uncle when aged 12, and played in high school band before receiving further education at [[Roosevelt University]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Grazian">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Grazian
| year= 2003
| title= Blue Chicago: The Search for Authenticity in Urban Blues Clubs
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Chicago Press]] 
| location= [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States
| isbn= 0-226-30568-6
| page= 130}}</ref> Jackson got married and worked as a private investigator then for the Illinois Department of Human Rights.<ref name="Electrofi"/>  By the mid 1980s, Jackson had relocated to [[Biloxi, Mississippi]].<ref name="AMG"/> His wholesale seafood business, Camel Seafood Company, was destroyed by [[Hurricane Elena]],<ref name="Electrofi"/> and Jackson immersed himself in blues music, inspired by the work of [[William R. Ferris]].  He learnt the music of [[Johnny Shines]], [[Howlin' Wolf]], [[Muddy Waters]] and the earlier [[Robert Johnson]] songs, with the view of working as an educator, activist and musician.<ref name="AMG"/>

Jackson appeared at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]] and [[Boundary Waters Blues Festival]], as well as working in schools across the United States.  He perfected two presentation styles to educate children about blues music, and he was known as Mr. Fruteland by those who he taught.  Jackson worked with the [[Blues Foundation]] to create a teaching program called "All About the Blues".  In 1996 the [[Illinois Arts Council]] granted him their Folk/Ethnic Heritage Award.  The Blues Foundation followed by naming Jackson as a recipient of their 'Keeping the Blues Alive Award.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1999 he published the educational book, ''Guitar Roots: Delta Blues - The roots of great guitar playing''.  He has also penned a one-act play entitled, ''The Life and Times of Robert Johnson''.<ref name="Delta"/>  

Also in 1999, Jackson was signed to a recording contract by Electro-Fi Records.<ref name="Electrofi"/> ''I Claim Nothing But the Blues'' (2000), was followed by ''Blues 2.0'' (2003).<ref name="AMG"/>  The latter was nominated for a W. C. Handy Award, and the magazine, ''Blues Revue'' named it "one of the finest blues albums of this young decade."<ref name="Electrofi"/> ''Tell Me what You Say'' was Jackson's latest album release in 2006.<ref name="AMG"/>

He remains based in Chicago.<ref name="AMG"/>
